Flushing, urticaria, conjunctival pruritus, bronchospasm, nausea, and vomiting usually develop within minutes to 1 hour if the antigen was injected or up to 2 hours if ingested.
Anaphylactic shock is caused by severe hypovolemia (fluid shifts owing to increased vascular permeability) and vasodilatation.
The diagnosis of anaphylaxis is made clinically. Death occurs from refractory bronchospasm, respiratory failure with upper airway obstruction, and cardiovascular collapse.
Consider latex allergy as the cause of anaphylaxis during surgery or anaphylaxis in a woman during coitus.
